title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
The White House said on Monday night it would lift the travel ban that has been in place since early last year on non-US citizens arriving to the US from the UK, the Republic of Ireland, the 26-nation Schengen common visa area of Europe and Brazil.

But a spokesman for the incoming president Joe Biden contradicted the announcement and said the ban would stay in place to stop the spread of coronavirus.

“With the pandemic worsening, and more contagious variants emerging around the world, this is not the time to be lifting restrictions on international travel,” Jen Psaki, Mr Biden's incoming White House press secretary, wrote on Twitter.

The confusion marks the start of Donald Trump's final full day in office, when he is expected to issue more than 100 pardons and commutations.

Meanwhile, as Mr Biden prepares to be sworn in as the 46th US president, protected by thousands of National Guard troops, he is facing a massive political challenge.

Having won the White House by projecting a mix of competence, empathy and renewal to American voters after four years of Trumpism, he will have to translate all that into governing at a wrenching moment in US history. 

Politically as much as economically, Mr Biden has reason to go big, urges our editorial board, to tackle the economic and health crises facing the country. More than a decade ago, Barack Obama trimmed his fiscal stimulus to account for conservative opposition and was subsequently routed in midterm elections. Democrats are well aware that to be successful, Mr Biden will need to show rapid concrete results. (CNN, FT)

Coronavirus digest

  • The US is expanding its ability to track coronavirus mutations with genomic sequencing as experts warned that new variants could be driving up cases and hospitalisations. (FT)

  • The UK, which inoculated 6 per cent of its population by the end of last week, has pulled ahead of other large advanced economies in the vaccination race. (FT)

  • The head of the World Health Organization warned the world was on the brink of “catastrophic moral failure” as poor countries fall behind richer ones in accessing Covid-19 vaccines. (FT)

  • The cost of shipping goods from China to Europe has more than tripled in the past eight weeks, as a shortage of empty containers stemming from the pandemic disrupts global trade. (FT)

In the news

Bets pile up against the dollar Speculative bets against the dollar have built up to the highest level in nearly three years despite the currency's near 1 per cent rebound this month, as investors such as hedge funds believe that looser monetary policy in the US means January's rebound will not last. (FT)

Evergrande shares soar Shares in China Evergrande surged nearly 17 per cent on Tuesday after the company's early repayment of a $2bn bond helped ease investor concerns about leverage at the world's most indebted property developer. (FT)

Mexico could find Biden a truculent neighbour President Andrés Manuel López Obrador kept things sweet with Donald Trump in exchange for little US “interference” with his domestic agenda, said one member of the US transition team. “A Biden presidency could be quite uncomfortable for Amlo,” he added. (FT)

IEA cuts estimate of 2021 oil demand Global oil demand will be lower in 2021 than previously expected, the International Energy Agency said on Tuesday, as renewed lockdowns to contain the pandemic hit consumption. (FT)

Workers will be lured back to the office, property manager predicts Investors are underestimating the speed and extent to which people will return to work in offices and head back to shopping malls as the pandemic subsides, the chief executive of the Canadian investment group Brookfield Asset Management told the FT. (FT)

Chinese university opens Budapest campus Hungary is to host the only Chinese university operating inside the EU, an indication of deepening ties between Viktor Orban's government and Beijing. Hungary will donate €2.2m to Shanghai-based Fudan University for its new campus, which the authorities said would start operating in 2024. (FT)

Thai court sentences woman to 43 years for insulting monarchy The conviction of Anchan Preelert, under the kingdom's tough lèse majesté law, came amid a crackdown against pro-democracy protesters. Civil liberties groups interpreted the verdict as a warning by Thailand's military-backed government to the country's six-month-old pro-democracy movement. (FT)

Samsung chief heads back to jail South Korea's appeals court has thrown Samsung's Lee Jae-yong back in jail for bribery in a landmark ruling that will leave the country's biggest conglomerate without its top decision maker for a year-and-a-half. (FT)

Russia jails Navalny for 30 days Prominent Vladimir Putin critic Alexei Navalny was sentenced to 30 days in jail a day after returning to Russia, triggering calls for sanctions from EU member states. There is no doubting Mr Navalny's courage, writes Ben Hall, or that today's Kremlin regards him as its greatest enemy. (FT)

The day ahead

Janet Yellen confirmation hearing The former Federal Reserve chair is to testify before the US Senate finance committee on her nomination to be Treasury secretary, when she will lay out the case for Joe Biden's proposed $1.9tn relief package. Global stocks rose ahead of the hearing. (FT)

Earnings Bank of America and Goldman Sachs follow JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and Wells Fargo last week and report fourth-quarter earnings on Tuesday. Netflix publishes results after markets close. (FT)

Italian PM faces crunch vote Italy's prime minister Giuseppe Conte faces a vote of confidence in the Senate after winning the vote in the lower house of parliament on Monday. Defeat would trigger a full-blown political crisis. (FT)

Former French PM's trial begins Edouard Balladur, prime minister between 1993 and 1995, faces allegations that kickbacks from a Pakistan arms deal helped fund his failed 1995 presidential attempt. (FT)

The Business of Football Summit is on February 17-18, featuring sessions with Manchester United striker and food poverty campaigner Marcus Rashford, Fifa general secretary Fatma Samoura, super-agent Jonathan Barnett and many more. Register here.

What else we're reading

America's disarray is China's opportunity A dispassionate assessment of world affairs, as it stands, cannot avoid the conclusion that the US is currently in deep trouble — and China is well placed to take advantage of that, writes Gideon Rachman. (FT)

How the far-right fell in line with Trump White supremacists tended to shun electoral politics as a feature of the corrupt world, scholars have said. But the outgoing US president has served as a beacon for a motley crew of extremists and a bridge to mainstream politics. The mob attack on the Capitol has also raised questions over a racial double standard in policing. (FT)

Higher inflation is coming and it will hit bondholders The historic increase in monetary supply to fight the Covid-19 crisis will lead to higher consumer prices, writes Jeremy Siegel. The FT's Markets editor Katie Martin says markets are approaching a boiled frog moment — ignoring the warning signs until it is too late. (FT)

Minimum wage is not a magic wand Unlike Edwardian Brits embarking on an experiment, the US has access to a wealth of empirical evidence about the effects of minimum wage rises, writes Sarah O'Connor. But a raise won't fix what is broken for America's working class on its own. (FT)

London's financial services let down by Brexit The financial services sector — worth £132bn a year to the UK and employing more than 1m people — has been neglected by a deal that is better for European exporters to the UK than it is for its world-leading service sector, writes London mayor Sadiq Khan. (FT)

Woman ruled dead fights to be declared alive Jeanne Pouchain has an unusual problem — she is officially dead. The 58-year-old has been trying since 2017 to prove that she is alive. French authorities took her car over an unpaid debt she contests. She fears the furniture will be next. (AP)

Video of the day

The race between vaccines and new variants Anna Gross lays out the threat new coronavirus variants pose to the UK's vaccination programme. The hopes of the rest of the world could depend upon whether Britain succeeds. (FT)
